[{'created': '2019-12-06 03:40:48.000000000', 'message': "Add locks to container image commands

Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21 added some additional
processing when uploading images. This unfortunately broke the
'openstack tripleo container image push' command because it assumes a
lock is always available. This change adds a process lock to the
ImageManagers used by the cli to ensure we are locking correctly when
doing any multiprocessing

Change-Id: I2d661682b3ee4d82d9f445a04e930c2fb328ef80
Closes-Bug: #1855184
(cherry picked from commit 94f8ef1df8d2a642c89fcb2838d0b8666aac0b08)
"}]
commit_message:
Add locks to container image commands

Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21 added some additional
processing when uploading images. This unfortunately broke the
'openstack tripleo container image push' command because it assumes a
lock is always available. This change adds a process lock to the
ImageManagers used by the cli to ensure we are locking correctly when
doing any multiprocessing

Change-Id: I2d661682b3ee4d82d9f445a04e930c2fb328ef80
Closes-Bug: #1855184
(cherry picked from commit 94f8ef1df8d2a642c89fcb2838d0b8666aac0b08)

commit_message:
add check for architecture

Currently, the image creation page doesn't provide architecture
check(but nova api does this job) and access to the architecutre
field on the image editing page.This makes the image very hard to
use with horizon.

Change-Id: Iffbadd729c270a957523ad8f1c648cb94c136c9c

commit_message:
Add Neutron network id to OVN LRPs

This patch is adding an external_id to the Logical_Router_Port
rows including the Neutron network ID.

The reason for this is that if we consume Octavia from Stein+ in
Rocky/Queens, this external id is missing and the OVN Octavia
driver (octavia_api) will not be able to apply the Load Balancers
to all the Logical Switches and Logical Routers where needed.

Note: This is a partial cherry-pick from
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668397/ since Octavia itself
does not exist in stable/queens but can be made to work
with neutron's stable/queens.

Change-Id: I4a0614afda8d2c2b8ccbb2583bc339a232fc802e
Co-Authored-By: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1855328
Related-Bug: #1794260
(cherry picked from commit aa4268a09470aea28f4a8c9f1062f32f057cb151)

> > i think it's better to put the most of them under

 > > as other drivers do.
 > 
 > We decided to move it to common/ module because those things are
 > used not only by mech driver but also L3 scheduler for ovn and
 > other stuff.
 > We have prepared at https://ethercalc.openstack.org/networking-ovn-migration
 > some plan what to move where exactly. Please take a look into that
 > and give us Your feedback about this plan. Maybe we should change
 > something there.

Exactly: constants and exceptions are used also in L3. Eventually we can move then to n-lib, but for now IMO we should move then to common/ovn"}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2019-11-28 13:51:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2019-11-28 14:51:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2019-11-28 15:02:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-11-28 15:09:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Patch Set 9 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2019-11-28 15:35:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2019-11-28 15:36:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2019-11-28 15:37:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-11-28 16:43:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

> if having them under ml2 is a problem, we can even have the top
 > level networking_ovn/ in neutron repo. my point is to put ovn
 > specific things together, clearly separated from the rest, rather
 > than sprinkling them to many places.
 > 
 > i think we should learn from the experiences of dvr, for which we
 > spread dvr-specific code too widely IMO.

I don't agree with the idea of segregating the OVN code in just one directory. The same as OVS or LB, we have constants, exceptions, auxiliary methods, ovsdb access librariesn plugins, etc. Each piece of this code should be located in the corresponding place, not in separate directory.

Why do we have the OVS ovsdb library in agent? And the OVS firewall? And all LB iptables methods?"}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-11-29 12:03:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Patch Set 15 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-11-29 14:30:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

 > > level networking_ovn/ in neutron repo. my point is to put ovn

 > > spread dvr-specific code too widely IMO.
 > 
 > I don't agree with the idea of segregating the OVN code in just one
 > directory. The same as OVS or LB, we have constants, exceptions,
 > auxiliary methods, ovsdb access librariesn plugins, etc. Each piece
 > of this code should be located in the corresponding place, not in
 > separate directory.
 > 
 > Why do we have the OVS ovsdb library in agent? And the OVS
 > firewall? And all LB iptables methods?

I agree with Rodolfo here. We should treat this driver as any other driver which is in-tree. IMO putting things in proper places in neutron tree will be more consistent with existing code base rather than creating separate module for ovn driver only"}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-11-29 15:33:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1

> The same as OVS or LB, we have constants, exceptions, auxiliary methods, ovsdb access librariesn plugins, etc. Each piece of this code should be located in the corresponding place, not in separate directory.

you can easily find counter examples under neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch.

> Why do we have the OVS ovsdb library in agent? And the OVS firewall? And all LB iptables methods?

some of them are libraries which can be used by other purposes. some of them are for historical reasons.

maybe purely library things from networking-ovn can be moved to an appropriate place. but for example utils.py in this patch seems highly ovn-specific to me.'}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2019-12-02 09:27:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(1 comment)

> > The same as OVS or LB, we have constants, exceptions, auxiliary
 > methods, ovsdb access librariesn plugins, etc. Each piece of this
 > code should be located in the corresponding place, not in separate
 > directory.
 >

And that's something we should avoid.

 > 
 > > Why do we have the OVS ovsdb library in agent? And the OVS
 > firewall? And all LB iptables methods?
 > 
 > some of them are libraries which can be used by other purposes.
 > some of them are for historical reasons.
 > 
 > maybe purely library things from networking-ovn can be moved to an
 > appropriate place. but for example utils.py in this patch seems
 > highly ovn-specific to me.

That's why those constants and methods are in common/ovn, separated from the rest. But those methods, although are OVN specific, do not depend on any library/backend/module and in a future could be called from anywhere else."}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-12-03 10:36:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

commit_message:
Fix api-ref roles response description

This patch removes the optional infront of the description
of roles API response. Since the response APIs fields are not
optional [1].

[1]https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/?expanded=list-roles-detail#roles

Change-Id: I8ada8d600bf3c096df7fe9f993f8a38b2e80bf86

commit_message:
Pass package list to Ansible package modules

Ansible no longer squashes loops for the package modules, so packages
are installed individually.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I2bdc70a35de884e2ca7f3b4bd459d221ec392c36

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-06 02:57:02.000000000', 'message': "Fix credential list for project members

Without this patch, project members and readers can list any credentials
with the /v3/credentials API when enforce_scope is false. enforce_scope
is only applicable to project admins due to the admin-ness problem[1],
and this policy is not meant to allow project admins any access to users'
credentials (only system admins should be able to access them). However,
when enforce_scope is false, we need to preserve the old behavior of
project admins being able to list all credentials. This change mitigates
the problem by running the identity:get_credential policy check to
filter out credentials the user does not have access to. This will
impact performance.

Closes-bug: #1855080

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/968696

Change-Id: I5dd85a6b8368373a27aef2942a64499d020662ef
(cherry picked from commit 17c337dbdbfb9d548ad531c2ad0483c9bce5b98f)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix credential list for project members

Without this patch, project members and readers can list any credentials
with the /v3/credentials API when enforce_scope is false. enforce_scope
is only applicable to project admins due to the admin-ness problem[1],
and this policy is not meant to allow project admins any access to users'
credentials (only system admins should be able to access them). However,
when enforce_scope is false, we need to preserve the old behavior of
project admins being able to list all credentials. This change mitigates
the problem by running the identity:get_credential policy check to
filter out credentials the user does not have access to. This will
impact performance.

Closes-bug: #1855080

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/968696

Change-Id: I5dd85a6b8368373a27aef2942a64499d020662ef
(cherry picked from commit 17c337dbdbfb9d548ad531c2ad0483c9bce5b98f)

Change-Id: I648caf97b532c65a0b1e12e8b27be9997a69780d
Closes-Bug: #1855149

commit_message:
Networks may be none

If the network vars are defined but not lists, the filters and loops
fail in ansible. We need to check that vars exist and that they aren't
none prior to using them.

Change-Id: I648caf97b532c65a0b1e12e8b27be9997a69780d
Closes-Bug: #1855149

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-25 08:59:25.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Implement engine graceful shutdown

Implements blueprint: mistral-graceful-scale-in

Change-Id: I6d1234dfa21b1e3420ec9ca2c5235dee973748ee
'}, {'created': '2019-11-25 09:42:51.000000000', 'message': 'Implement engine graceful shutdown

* The functionality of graceful engine shutdown is now possible
  due to correct calculation of the "graceful" flag in the engine
  server's stop() method. Unfortunately, the Oslo Service framework
  doesn't pass it correctly, it simply ignores it in the call chain.
  So the only way to understand if the shutdown is graceful is to
  peek at the configuration property "graceful_shutdown_timeout"
  provided by Oslo Service. If it's greater than zero then we can
  treat it as graceful.
* Oslo Service handles only four OS signals: SIGTERM, SIGINT,
  SIGHUP and SIGALRM. Only sending SIGTERM to the process leads
  to a graceful shutdown. For example, SIGINT (which is equal to
  ctrl + C in a unix shell) interrupts the process immediately.
  So the only way to do a graceful shutdown of an engine instance
  using a unix shell is to run the "kill <PID>" command. This
  needs to be taken into account when using it.
* The patch also changes the order in which the engine server
  stops its inner services so that the underlying RPC server
  (currently Oslo Messaging based or Kombu based) stops first.
  This is needed to make sure that, first of all, no new RPC
  calls can arrive, and thereby, let all active DB transactions
  finish normally w/o starting new ones. Stopping the RPC server
  may be a heavy operation if there are already lots of RPC
  messages waiting for processing that are polled from the queue.
  So to the great extent the entire functionality of graceful
  shutdown will depend on whether an underlying RPC server
  implements the corresponding functionality in the proper way,
  i.e. after calling stop(graceful=True) it will stop receiving
  new calls and wait till all buffered RPC messages are processed
  normally.
* The maximum time given to graceful shutdown is controlled via
  the "graceful_shutdown_timeout" configuration option, which is
  60 seconds, by default.
* Minor refactoring

Implements blueprint: mistral-graceful-scale-in

Change-Id: I6d1234dfa21b1e3420ec9ca2c5235dee973748ee
'}, {'created': '2019-12-06 09:29:26.000000000', 'message': 'Implement engine graceful shutdown

* Oslo Service handles only four OS signals: SIGTERM, SIGINT,
  SIGHUP and SIGALRM. Only sending SIGTERM to the process leads
  to a graceful shutdown. For example, SIGINT (which is equal to
  ctrl + C in a unix shell) interrupts the process immediately.
  So the only way to do a graceful shutdown of an engine instance
  using a unix shell is to run the "kill <PID>" command. This
  needs to be taken into account when using it.
* The patch also changes the order in which the engine server
  stops its inner services so that the underlying RPC server
  (currently Oslo Messaging based or Kombu based) stops first.
  This is needed to make sure that, first of all, no new RPC
  calls can arrive, and thereby, let all active DB transactions
  finish normally w/o starting new ones. Stopping the RPC server
  may be a heavy operation if there are already lots of RPC
  messages waiting for processing that are polled from the queue.
  So to the great extent the entire functionality of graceful
  shutdown will depend on whether an underlying RPC server
  implements the corresponding functionality in the proper way,
  i.e. after calling stop(graceful=True) it will stop receiving
  new calls and wait till all buffered RPC messages are processed
  normally.
* The maximum time given to graceful shutdown is controlled via
  the "graceful_shutdown_timeout" configuration option, which is
  60 seconds, by default.
* Minor refactoring

Implements blueprint: mistral-graceful-scale-in

Change-Id: I6d1234dfa21b1e3420ec9ca2c5235dee973748ee

commit_message:
Implement engine graceful shutdown

* The functionality of graceful engine shutdown is now possible
  due to correct calculation of the "graceful" flag in the engine
  server's stop() method. Unfortunately, the Oslo Service framework
  doesn't pass it correctly, it simply ignores it in the call chain.
  So the only way to understand if the shutdown is graceful is to
  peek at the configuration property "graceful_shutdown_timeout"
  provided by Oslo Service. If it's greater than zero then we can
  treat it as graceful.
* Oslo Service handles only four OS signals: SIGTERM, SIGINT,
  SIGHUP and SIGALRM. Only sending SIGTERM to the process leads
  to a graceful shutdown. For example, SIGINT (which is equal to
  ctrl + C in a unix shell) interrupts the process immediately.
  So the only way to do a graceful shutdown of an engine instance
  using a unix shell is to run the "kill <PID>" command. This
  needs to be taken into account when using it.
* The patch also changes the order in which the engine server
  stops its inner services so that the underlying RPC server
  (currently Oslo Messaging based or Kombu based) stops first.
  This is needed to make sure that, first of all, no new RPC
  calls can arrive, and thereby, let all active DB transactions
  finish normally w/o starting new ones. Stopping the RPC server
  may be a heavy operation if there are already lots of RPC
  messages waiting for processing that are polled from the queue.
  So to the great extent the entire functionality of graceful
  shutdown will depend on whether an underlying RPC server
  implements the corresponding functionality in the proper way,
  i.e. after calling stop(graceful=True) it will stop receiving
  new calls and wait till all buffered RPC messages are processed
  normally.
* The maximum time given to graceful shutdown is controlled via
  the "graceful_shutdown_timeout" configuration option, which is
  60 seconds, by default.
* Minor refactoring

Implements blueprint: mistral-graceful-scale-in

Change-Id: I6d1234dfa21b1e3420ec9ca2c5235dee973748ee

commit_message:
Ensure we set proper SELinux label on container-puppet.sh

Just to ensure we have the right label, even if something does mount the
directory with re-labelling. This would avoid any race-condition chance.

Also update old svirt_sandbox_file_t alias since the common thing is
"container_file_t".

Change-Id: Ic036ad901885f9d8c8072b560f2d9f3c8e919d58
Closes-Bug: #1854377
(cherry picked from commit 3b146b1e45fbf3a7829128eeb6dd510f9f21b278)

commit_message:
Use release and dlrn_hash/tag var instead of hardcoded value

in ovb and ovb-rdocloud.yaml, for RHEL-8 overcloud_image_url and
ipa_image_url, release and dlrn_hash/tag was hardcoded to master
and due to this master image gets pulled in train job also leading
to unwanted to RHEL8 fs01 train job.

Closes-Bug: #1853978

Change-Id: I737c6c272448eca14683b845563102afd0fc0f96
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

Something has changed because this fails with ExternalNetworkAttachForbidden now:

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/540a9fc0dbc64abb92d3f3e513573307/log/compute1/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz#37415

+ /opt/stack/nova/gate/post_test_hook.sh:main:166 :   openstack --os-compute-api-version 2.72 server create --image 68e02cbf-69ae-4480-bd0a-a02f50bbd24d --flavor 1 --nic net-id=29715f6f-24ab-49b7-abff-60d3f97596a0 --nic port-id=port-normal-qos --wait heal-allocations-test
Error creating server: heal-allocations-test
Error creating server

This is the network for the port we're using:

+ /opt/stack/nova/gate/post_test_hook.sh:main:120 :   openstack network create net0 --provider-network-type vlan --provider-physical-network public --provider-segment 100 --project demo
+---------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Field                     | Value                                                                                                                                            |

| location                  | cloud='', project.domain_id=, project.domain_name=, project.id='5e899e65a6fc46ba9e8bf4210c4a6a2e', project.name=, region_name='RegionOne', zone= |
| mtu                       | 1450                                                                                                                                             |
| name                      | net0                                                                                                                                             |
| port_security_enabled     | True                                                                                                                                             |
| project_id                | 5e899e65a6fc46ba9e8bf4210c4a6a2e                                                                                                                 |

| subnets                   |                                                                                                                                                  |
| tags                      |                                                                                                                                                  |
| updated_at                | 2019-11-13T15:35:09Z                                                                                                                             |
+---------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

Note:

router:external           | Internal
shared                    | False

It seems our logic for "router:external" here is wrong now?

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/dcfd74fb37d0be788b24d17d1089f232f05ceed8/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py#L540

That appears to expect router:external to be a boolean but it's an enum now.

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html#external-network also says it's a boolean. Something must have recently regressed in neutron.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-13 17:32:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Reported a neutron bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1852468'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-13 17:51:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The "Internal" value is OSC translating the False value:

https://github.com/openstack/python-openstackclient/blob/d17a1c8039807cdac29e77eb5f0724d181bdd831/openstackclient/network/v2/network.py#L33

So router:external=False and shared=False but then why would this be True?

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/dcfd74fb37d0be788b24d17d1089f232f05ceed8/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py#L540

if net.get('router:external') and not net.get('shared'):

-> if False and True

I wonder if there is some kind of race?'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-12-03 09:39:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review -Workflow

I might misunderstood something but based on the log the server that is failed to boot does not user the net0 you quoted above but uses the 'public' net 

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/540a9fc0dbc64abb92d3f3e513573307/log/job-output.txt#79553

recheck see what happens'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-05 15:30:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I might misunderstood something but based on the log the server that is failed to boot does not user the net0 you quoted above but uses the 'public' net 

Hmm, then something is wrong because the OSC command to get the network should be filtering out shared=False networks:

openstack network list --no-share -f value -c ID

Should we just hard-code the network used to create the server to be net0? I'm not sure why we don't do that anyway.

I'm guessing the wrinkle introduced with this patch is we're using a different project so we're getting access to different networks."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-05 15:32:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-05 15:36:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

OK I see, 29715f6f-24ab-49b7-abff-60d3f97596a0 is a public external but not shared network. external != shared. So we're getting the public external non-shared network and using that to create the server, which fails because by default policy in nova you can't create a server as a non-admin on an external network."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-05 15:44:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-05 15:45:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Regression test for bug 1849657

This attempts to recreate bug 1849657 by creating a non-admin
server using a port with resource allocation requests as part
of our integration testing in the nova-next post_test_script run.

Change-Id: Ia615fda562db5096f855911997645e190150c9f7
Related-Bug: #1849657

commit_message:
Added python3 packages for mellanox agent container

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672023 added mellanox agent
container which contains python2 packages but on RHEL8 tripleo
job, python3 packages are needed which broke the periodic
container build job, including python3 packages will
fix the issue.

Closes-Bug: #1855050

Change-Id: I35909eccaa101ef498d0a3481b8708d8ee5884d3
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-05 07:55:14.000000000', 'message': "Adding member to image fails for multiple stores

If multiple stores is enabled then adding member to image fails with
UnknownScheme: Unknown scheme 'XXXX' found in URI while setting _acls
to the store.

Made provision to call 'set_acls_for_multi_store' if multiple stores
are enabled.

(backport note: change name 'store' back to 'backend' since it is
before the bp:multi-store-vocabulary-correction)

Change-Id: I7594185396f7a58a3c0aeeacab891b5eb18a8bf3
Closes-Bug: #1838332
(cherry picked from commit aca6996ea93d4ab491a996e714831adb82888ad3)
"}]
commit_message:
Adding member to image fails for multiple stores

If multiple stores is enabled then adding member to image fails with
UnknownScheme: Unknown scheme 'XXXX' found in URI while setting _acls
to the store.

Made provision to call 'set_acls_for_multi_store' if multiple stores
are enabled.

(backport note: change name 'store' back to 'backend' since it is
before the bp:multi-store-vocabulary-correction)

Change-Id: I7594185396f7a58a3c0aeeacab891b5eb18a8bf3
Closes-Bug: #1838332
(cherry picked from commit aca6996ea93d4ab491a996e714831adb82888ad3)

subject: Re-install osc-placement after nova
messages: [{'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-11-21 16:22:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-11-21 16:23:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-12-06 20:23:31.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned\n\nDon't think this is needed anymore"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-21 16:22:58.000000000', 'message': "Re-install osc-placement after nova

When running grenade under python3, nova runs under python2.  Swift
includes openstack client in its requirements so when it installs under
Python 2 it clobbers the existing openstack client at /usr/local/bin and
any previously installed plugins are wiped out because their entry
points aren't seen. This was discovered because the osc-placement
commands were not available to nova inventory verification commands
during the nova upgrade, which comes after swift.

To address this, we do a reinstall at the end of nova's upgrade.
Because python-openstack client is in ENABLED_PYTHON3_PACKAGES,
it will install as Python3 when installed standalone.

Note that the issue being fixed here is python3 specific, not
OpenStack release specific.

Change-Id: I6e2fc34d44be0f8b28054dbd4e6f82c5d35f1c93
"}]
commit_message:
Re-install osc-placement after nova

When running grenade under python3, nova runs under python2.  Swift
includes openstack client in its requirements so when it installs under
Python 2 it clobbers the existing openstack client at /usr/local/bin and
any previously installed plugins are wiped out because their entry
points aren't seen. This was discovered because the osc-placement
commands were not available to nova inventory verification commands
during the nova upgrade, which comes after swift.

To address this, we do a reinstall at the end of nova's upgrade.
Because python-openstack client is in ENABLED_PYTHON3_PACKAGES,
it will install as Python3 when installed standalone.

Note that the issue being fixed here is python3 specific, not
OpenStack release specific.

Change-Id: I6e2fc34d44be0f8b28054dbd4e6f82c5d35f1c93

commit_message:
Create python3 Centos-7 scenario job

Create the octavia-v2-dsvm-py3-scenario-centos-7 and
associated job definitions for consumption in the
Octavia repository.

Also change the octavia-v2-dsvm-scenario-centos-7 job
to default to being python3 as it's non-voting anyways.

Change-Id: Ic22604fa277d4e996c9f9197b6d36b4f7149e6d8

commit_message:
Replace/remove multiple deprecated options in group DEFAULT

 * Replace 'logdir' by 'log_dir', on versions >= mikata
 * Remove 'vnc_enabled' and refactor VNC options, on versions >= mikata
 * Remove 'use_neutron', on versions >= ocata
 * Remove 'force_dhcp_release', on versions >= ocata
 * Remove 'firewall_driver', on versions >= pike
 * Remove 'dhcpbridge', on versions >= pike
 * Remove 'dhcpbridge_flagfile', on versions >= pike
 * Remove 'disable_libvirt_livesnapshot', on versions >= stein
 * Update the stein template to use scheme/address instead of live_migration_uri

Change-Id: I73b85866d4e83fb04ce5a776afedeaecfe3f98c5
Closes-bug: #1853560

commit_message:
Remove skydive rpm installation

Since some time (around v0.22.0) skydive team has stopped publishing
rpm packages in centos-opstools repo - instead they moved into
producing docker images for consumption.

This change removes usage of rpms for rpm distros and uses GitHub release
binary as in deb distros.

Change-Id: Ie586b0f249e545877ab1dd156d08e1863cd479ba

[{'created': '2019-11-27 16:06:21.000000000', 'message': 'Do not update root_device_name during guest config

_get_guest_config() is currently updating instance.root_device_name
and called in many ways like:

_hard_reboot(), rescue(), spawn(), resume(), finish_migration(),
finish_revert_migration()

It is an issue because root_device_name is initally set during instance
build and should remain the same after:

manager.py: _do_build_and_run_instance()
             ..
               _default_block_device_names() <-here
               ..
               driver.spawn()

This may lead to edge case, like in rescue where this value can be mistakenly
updated to reflect disk bus property of rescue image (hw_disk_bus).
Further more, a _get* method should not modify instance object.

Note that test test_get_guest_config_bug_1118829 is removed because no more
relevant with current code.

Change-Id: I1787f9717618d0837208844e8065840d30341cf7
Closes-Bug: #1835926
(cherry picked from commit 5e0ed5e7fee3c4c887263a0e9fa847c2dcc5cf3b)
'}]
commit_message:
Do not update root_device_name during guest config

_get_guest_config() is currently updating instance.root_device_name
and called in many ways like:

_hard_reboot(), rescue(), spawn(), resume(), finish_migration(),
finish_revert_migration()

It is an issue because root_device_name is initally set during instance
build and should remain the same after:

manager.py: _do_build_and_run_instance()
             ..
               _default_block_device_names() <-here
               ..
               driver.spawn()

This may lead to edge case, like in rescue where this value can be mistakenly
updated to reflect disk bus property of rescue image (hw_disk_bus).
Further more, a _get* method should not modify instance object.

Note that test test_get_guest_config_bug_1118829 is removed because no more
relevant with current code.

Change-Id: I1787f9717618d0837208844e8065840d30341cf7
Closes-Bug: #1835926
(cherry picked from commit 5e0ed5e7fee3c4c887263a0e9fa847c2dcc5cf3b)

commit_message:
refactor: RequestGroup.is_empty() and .strip_zeros()

This makes an is_empty() method on RequestGroup which answers whether
the group has any resources, traits, or aggregates; and a strip_zeros()
method which removes any resources whose amount is zero.

These are used to refactor ResourceRequest.strip_zeros().
_clean_empties() becomes not worth keeping in its own method, so it's
rolled into ResourceRequest.strip_zeros(), its only consumer. At the
same time, the worthless (at least now that we're py3-only)
ResourceRequest.resource_groups() generator is removed and inlined in
the couple of places it was used.

In addition to simply making the code more cohesive, a later patch will
make use of RequestGroup.is_empty() to forbid no-op groups coming from
ports, accelerators, etc.

Change-Id: I6a83b0eb0f1c352f197f2ef8fab124decd537270

[{'created': '2019-09-05 02:27:04.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Adds configuration and enables the Ironic Inspector

This commit enables and configures the Ironic Inspector. This feature
allows for baremetal nodes to be introspected. This provides useful
information about an Ironic host. Such information includes harware
and mac addresses.

Change-Id: I2ee09d9cc20f9b8e4430c55129cd8bac9435299d

commit_message:
Adds configuration for the Ironic Inspector

This commit enables and configures the Ironic Inspector. This feature
allows for baremetal nodes to be introspected. This provides useful
information about an Ironic host. Such information includes harware
and mac addresses.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/680553
Change-Id: I2ee09d9cc20f9b8e4430c55129cd8bac9435299d

commit_message:
Replace WSME and Pecan with Werkzeug

WSME is no longer maintained and Pecan is an overkill for our (purely
internal) API. This change rewrites the API in Werkzeug (the library
underneath Flask). I don't use Flask here since it's also an overkill
for API with 4 meaningful endpoints.

Change-Id: Ifed45f70869adf00e795202a53a2a53c9c57ef30

> (5 comments)
 > 
 > Couple of suggestions inline and also the functional test failure
 > is a valid one failing on placement a_c query schema validation.

So we need to bump the microversion in the placement query to 1.34'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-29 15:00:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

(1 comment)

Thanks for the early look, gibi. I got to the end of the day far from done with this (see commit message), mainly saving my work. I definitely still need to bump the placement microversion, but I also need to finish tying the requester_id into the port resources and swap out the whole mechanism used to set the mappings. (Wonder if there's a way to split this into two or more patches...)

I like your suggestion of forcing the externally provided groups to have suffixes. I'm doing this with the cyborg effort in mind, and the patches as currently proposed don't have that - they were relying on generating numeric ones like the code did before. But it would be better (and not too hard) to do as you say, so I'll change that.

Thanks again."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-12-02 13:28:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 29963, 'date': '2019-12-02 13:58:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Build SUCCESSFUL (check pipeline).

- pmem-tempest-plugin-filtered http://52.27.155.124/18/696418/2/check/pmem-tempest-plugin-filtered/3e5e43f/ : SUCCESS in 28m 22s'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-12-02 14:23:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Thanks for the early look, gibi. I got to the end of the day far
 > from done with this (see commit message), mainly saving my work. I
 > definitely still need to bump the placement microversion, but I
 > also need to finish tying the requester_id into the port resources
 > and swap out the whole mechanism used to set the mappings. (Wonder
 > if there's a way to split this into two or more patches...)

One patch can simply bump the used a_c microversion without using the mapping from the response. This bump patch should be fairly simple. Then a later patch can start using the mapping from the a_c response. Honestly I feel that there will be dragons there but I would have to do it to see what kind and where. 

 > 
 > I like your suggestion of forcing the externally provided groups to
 > have suffixes. I'm doing this with the cyborg effort in mind, and
 > the patches as currently proposed don't have that - they were
 > relying on generating numeric ones like the code did before. But it
 > would be better (and not too hard) to do as you say, so I'll change
 > that.

cool

 > 
 > Thanks again."}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-12-02 15:51:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Use Placement 1.34 (string suffixes & mappings)

This commit cuts us over to using placement microversion 1.34 for GET
/allocation_candidates, thereby supporting string request group suffixes
(added in 1.33) when specified in flavor extra_specs.

The mappings (added in 1.34) are not used in code yet, but a future
patch will tie the group suffixes to the RequestGroup.requester_id so
that it can be correlated after GET /a_c. This will allow us to get rid
of map_requested_resources_to_providers, which was a hack to bridge the
gap until we had mappings from placement.

Change-Id: I52499ff6639c1a5815a8557b22dd33106dcc386b

commit_message:
Fix kolla-ansible role tests

The kolla-ansible CLI now requires the kolla_ansible python module to be
importable. We need to activate the virtualenv to make this work.

Change-Id: I43d4761409df3eea146dc7ff16b4c8d80855a91b
(cherry picked from commit 994d7902439789a63cf42caf1c0102349a2b9fb2)

commit_message:
ovn-base: Create /run/ovn in extend_start.sh

OVN 2.12 packages are not creating /run/ovn directory,
which is the default socket/pidfile path for ovn services.

Change-Id: I9cf8c9a4fafeab00f76ee70a123b9a841aa77512

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-26 18:15:52.000000000', 'message': 'compute: Take an instance.uuid lock when rebooting

Previously simultaneous requests to reboot and delete an instance could
race as only the latter took a lock against the uuid of the instance.

With the Libvirt driver this race could potentially result in attempts
being made to reconnect previously disconnected volumes on the host.
Depending on the volume backend being used this could then result in
stale block devices point to unmapped volumes being left on the host
that in turn could cause failures later on when connecting newly mapped
volumes.

This change avoids this race by ensuring any request to reboot an
instance takes an instance.uuid lock within the compute manager,
serialising requests to reboot and then delete the instance.

Closes-Bug: #1838392
Change-Id: Ieb59de10c63bb067f92ec054535766cdd722dae2
(cherry picked from commit 9ad54f3dacbd372271f441baea5380f913072dde)
(cherry picked from commit 939cd9b177db8f12952e72145a5c00a0574959eb)
'}]
commit_message:
compute: Take an instance.uuid lock when rebooting

Previously simultaneous requests to reboot and delete an instance could
race as only the latter took a lock against the uuid of the instance.

With the Libvirt driver this race could potentially result in attempts
being made to reconnect previously disconnected volumes on the host.
Depending on the volume backend being used this could then result in
stale block devices point to unmapped volumes being left on the host
that in turn could cause failures later on when connecting newly mapped
volumes.

This change avoids this race by ensuring any request to reboot an
instance takes an instance.uuid lock within the compute manager,
serialising requests to reboot and then delete the instance.

Closes-Bug: #1838392
Change-Id: Ieb59de10c63bb067f92ec054535766cdd722dae2
(cherry picked from commit 9ad54f3dacbd372271f441baea5380f913072dde)
(cherry picked from commit 939cd9b177db8f12952e72145a5c00a0574959eb)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-24 13:07:37.000000000', 'message': "Use docker_custom_config variable

In the Train cycle, Kolla Ansible added support for
docker_custom_config, and writes out configuration to
/etc/docker/daemon.json. This will conflict with Kayobe's configuration
of that file, and changes made by kayobe will be reversed when
kolla-ansible bootstrap-servers is run.

This change uses the new variable to pass daemon.json configuration
through to kolla ansible. Because the ordering has changed, we also need
to separate out the devicemapper setup and run this prior to starting
docker.

Change-Id: Idc3fa9fefd8242ef9db76d4d773885e3594b453a
Story: 2006764
Task: 37277

commit_message:
Use docker_custom_config variable

In the Train cycle, Kolla Ansible added support for
docker_custom_config, and writes out configuration to
/etc/docker/daemon.json. This will conflict with Kayobe's configuration
of that file, and changes made by kayobe will be reversed when
kolla-ansible bootstrap-servers is run.

This change uses the new variable to pass daemon.json configuration
through to kolla ansible. Because the ordering has changed, we also need
to separate out the devicemapper setup and run this prior to starting
docker.

Change-Id: Idc3fa9fefd8242ef9db76d4d773885e3594b453a
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/691001
Story: 2006764
Task: 37277

commit_message:
Elasticsearch: Remove unnecessary rbac definitions

This removes the cluster role definition from the Elasticsearch
component templates, as these are not needed for the service to
function correctly.

Change-Id: I671272affbed8984a47121187024e4b831937123
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

As the tripleo-lab maintainer I might see some advantages for this "central" set of roles, of course

But, seeing that we're dismembering part if not all of the CLI in order to move to proper ansible roles, I'm wondering if we shouldn't put our energy on that job instead of going ahead with those "cloud operators roles".

In the end, if we could "just" get a set of proper playbooks instead of the tripleoclient (for the install/update/upgrade part), I'm pretty sure everyone will be happy.

So unless this moves toward the "no more CLI" direction we're seeing for other tools (paunch for instance), I think we shouldn't lose time on that, and put energy in mistral2ansible, tht2ta and other efforts that effectively drop codes/tools in order to converge to ansible.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-11-18 16:06:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Cedric, I don't think we should get rid of the cli from an end user standpoint because operators may need to do something out of band and doing it via ansible can be awkward/awful.  The target of this should be in parallel with the other tht2ansible and other effrots as those would be the actual deployment (internal) implementations for the tripleo actions while this is the layer that operators actually interact with.  I don't think the paunch bits necessarily related with this effort because paunch was always an internal implementation detail that was more for developer usage than operator usage."}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-11-18 16:27:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

All discussions included, I'm happy to see this go ahead. While I think we initially may have to set a minimum OSP version to scope the work involved, over time we may be able to backtrack some things to try and eliminate the use of this and disparate CI tools."}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-11-18 16:43:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

This is exactly what many people have been asking for, simple automation around deploying TripleO. I think this can definitely provide a lot of value to cloud operators and will help consolidate all of our CI tools to use a standardized interface.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-11-18 21:58:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-11-18 22:02:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-11-18 22:04:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2019-11-18 22:05:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 27427, 'date': '2019-11-20 18:13:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

A word of caution about reinventing the wheel, but on the whole I'm all for this spec as it stands."}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-11-20 19:04:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

For me, the end goal of this is to take the best existing parts of what we have now (TripleO-Quickstart, InfraRed, etc.) and consolidate that into a standard framework. This should make it easier for everyone (operators, dev, support, etc.) to consume and deploy TripleO. This should also promote more cross-team collaboration on these Ansible bits.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2019-11-20 20:52:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2019-11-20 20:56:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-12-04 13:30:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

Pavel had expressed my thoughts very well. I tend to agree and propose the scope of the spec to be clarified. In the case it is only to provide additional abstraction layer wrapping miscellaneous data pipes and CLI tripleoclient commands, f. e. to generate all network environment files to describe Spine & Leaf for a 1000 leafs, or generating environments for NFV and HPC setups, that scope totally makes sense perhaps.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-12-04 13:33:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

another great example for "data pipes" could be split-stack inputs generation for multiple stacks'}, {'account_id': 17216, 'date': '2019-12-04 14:21:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-12-04 14:40:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

The initial scope is not going to include additional data generation hence why it's not specified as such in the spec. We can investigate further improvements as we get feedback on the usage of this effort but the initial goal is purely the basics.  I appreciate the comments but I think they are outside the scope of this effort at this time. This is something that's been asked for externally so this effort is to get something out this cycle."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-12-04 15:04:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 14345, 'date': '2019-12-04 17:34:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-12-04 17:46:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14345, 'date': '2019-12-05 13:17:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

+1 Overall I have to say I understand the need for this project, moving the weight of API maintenance from duplication in various projects closer to TripleO development, but imho it is coming little bit late (it was already implemented in various tools; in downstream with very little possibility to change currently, and because of next point, also in future).

-1 Since downstream (IR) is moving to branched and has to maintain sometimes >7 OSP versions back, it could be difficult to adopt/maintain long-term and sync between. Also I tend to agree with psedlak with concerns about the scope covered with these new roles, maybe the narrow scope is not enough and at least templating (around inputs) could be included, since templates and CLI calls are usually tightly-coupled.

=0'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-12-05 14:39:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Just because infrared might branch doesn't mean they can't leverage this since it'll be an independent package. It actually makes it easier to consume downstream if infrared was branched because then only newer versions might consume this and you wouldn't have to backport the implementation if you don't want.  As for templating, that shouldn't matter because the interface will just be file paths. So that doesn't need to be part of this at all.  

As for this being too late, yes, yes it is. but we still need it"}, {'account_id': 23811, 'date': '2019-12-06 12:44:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2019-12-06 18:01:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Create ansible roles for cloud operator actions

The cli has traditionally been the only supported interface for
deploying tripleo. This however has lead to multiple implementations of
roles to perform the various tripleo actions. We should establish a
small supported set of ansible roles, modules and plugins that can be
used when writing automation around TripleO deployments.

Change-Id: I8ac853b78f57661f53f77cb185806461d7f029f2

This updates the Elasticsearch and Kibana charts to deploy
version 7.1.0. This move required significant changes to both
charts, including: changing elasticsearch masters to a statefulset
to utilize reliable dns names for the discovery process, config
updates to reflect deprecated/updated/removed values, use the
kibana saved objects api for managing index patterns and setting
the default index, and updating the elasticsearch entrypoint
scripts to reflect the use of elastic-keystore for storing s3
credentials instead of defining them in the configuration file

commit_message:
Elasticsearch/Kibana: Update version to 7.1.0

This updates the Elasticsearch and Kibana charts to deploy
version 7.1.0. This move required significant changes to both
charts, including: changing elasticsearch masters to a statefulset
to utilize reliable dns names for the discovery process, config
updates to reflect deprecated/updated/removed values, use the
kibana saved objects api for managing index patterns and setting
the default index, and updating the elasticsearch entrypoint
scripts to reflect the use of elastic-keystore for storing s3
credentials instead of defining them in the configuration file

Change-Id: I270d905f266fc15492e47d8376714ba80603e66d
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

Change-Id: Ide422b7b60a0b3a9321fb4686f0a2ab922200b7e

commit_message:
Also keep old_style blacklist schema

The blacklist defined for older release with in the job
does not have test attributes leading to break the role.

In order to have compatibility between older blacklist and
newer blacklist having test tag schema fixes the issue.

Change-Id: Ide422b7b60a0b3a9321fb4686f0a2ab922200b7e
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix kolla-ansible role tests

The kolla-ansible CLI now requires the kolla_ansible python module to be
importable. We need to activate the virtualenv to make this work.

Change-Id: I43d4761409df3eea146dc7ff16b4c8d80855a91b

commit_message:
Support installing packages in IPA images

Diskimage builder supports specifying a list of packages to install via
-p. We currently support this for the root image, but not IPA images.

This change adds a new configuration option, 'ipa_build_dib_packages',
that should be a list of additional packages to install in locally built
IPA images. This affects the following commands:

kayobe seed deployment image build
kayobe overcloud deployment image build

This depends on
https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-role-os-images/pull/25.

Also adds an example to the documentation for the equivalent option for
root image.

Change-Id: I04191d9541894b6a264e966c9ecb1056e0edade4
Story: 2006855
Task: 37446

commit_message:
Add new variables for customising the deployment image in Bifrost

Add new variables, ``kolla_bifrost_dib_elements_extra`` and
``kolla_bifrost_dib_env_vars_extra``, in
``${KAYOBE_CONFIG_PATH}/bifrost.yml`` for setting additional
``diskimage-builder`` elements and environment variables for the disk
image generated by Bifrost. Default elements and environment variables
are now respectively defined by ``kolla_bifrost_dib_elements_default``
and ``kolla_bifrost_dib_env_vars_default``.

Change-Id: I22ab15c42d8db772f1a64f325f9371860491ccfb

commit_message:
Remove sphinx from test-requirements.txt

Documentation build environments use doc/requirements.txt where sphinx
is already present. Use doc/requirements.txt in the pep8 environment
because sphinx is required by sphinx8.

Change-Id: I3a2c9ae392745e001c5bdd01212c996e54c44f0c

Changed default identity url to horizon

The keystone doesn't use 5000 port anymore from Newton version. And all
 the references should be changed together.

commit_message:
Switch to stable/train for source images on CentOS/RHEL

OpenStack projects are beginning to drop python 2 support on the master
branch. CentOS 8 is not yet ready, so our best option to continue
building and testing CentOS is to use the Train tarballs for source
images.

This change also introduces a new openstack_branch config option which
can be used to set the branch used for source images. For CentOS/RHEL,
the default is stable-train, for Debian/Ubuntu it it master.

Change-Id: Ieab5e06a3c05951d97bb979ab735b4cef675cc0a

commit_message:
Fix catching driver exceptions

octavia_lib driver exceptions were not cought by call_provider
This patch add those exceptions, and also handles the native NotImplementedError
which does nto have all the expected fields.

Change-Id: I1a566353b7fb125184849b3a0f864d3ef6896d94
(cherry picked from commit e2defa6dd238d82ce4ee457e21ca047888d27106)

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

heat-dashboard is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Also this patch update minimum tox version in tox.ini file.
Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: I63d6c5dfb2bb312c413b9350fa7c9a01eae6cd0b

commit_message:
Dejokerizes 404 logs.

Removes Super Mario jokes on log messages of 404 errors. Even though
people find them funny (myself included), they don't add any value to
the log itself.

Change-Id: I9b6c648cd7bdedcc2ad7c2dea649bc19642afff0
Story: 2006532
Task: 36588
Signed-off-by: Moisés Guimarães de Medeiros <moguimar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
mdns: correctly handle loopback addresses

Currently an UnboundLocalError is raised when all addresses are
loopback, raise ServiceLookupFailure instead.

Change-Id: I7db3603d382c0cb4b81b94e2382ecd3a191f6977

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23253, 'date': '2019-05-07 07:33:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26936, 'date': '2019-05-07 19:10:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-05-10 07:10:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Hi! Unfortunately, I don't have time for a proper explanation, but at the PTG we discussed a very similar feature for marking nodes as failed by 3rd party monitoring. While it does not sound similar, the technical implementation is expected to be nearly identical. I wonder if we can merge these features together. Please see https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/DEN-train-ironic-ptg around line 360."}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-05-10 08:03:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi Dmitry. Thanks, sounds good! I'll put this on the agenda for the next meeting to discuss how we can move this forward."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-05-10 16:03:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-05-10 16:29:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)

Thanks for the review, Doug! I replied inline but suggest to wait if this could be embedded into a wider feature/spec which covers the request Dmitry mentions.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-05-12 17:08:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-05-12 18:44:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-05-12 19:30:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-05-13 15:55:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-05-13 16:16:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

From IRC discussion [1] unclear how this should be supported (flag vs state vs some other mechanism). 

Some additional points to consider include:
* consumer API impact (e.g. nova not considering the node for scheduling)
* impact on the allocation API
* retiring a node should probably be possible from any state
* support could be combined with a feature discussed at the ptg: "taking nodes out of service without deleting them"

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/ironic/2019/ironic.2019-05-13-15.10.log.html'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-05-14 07:35:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

removing vote after recent discussions, there's still uncertainty on how to the actual design"}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-05-21 17:23:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> From IRC discussion [1] unclear how this should be supported (flag
 > vs state vs some other mechanism).
 > 
 > Some additional points to consider include:
 > * consumer API impact (e.g. nova not considering the node for
 > scheduling)

I think this is easily addressed. The nova code defaults to counting available afaik.

 > * impact on the allocation API
This data is filtered via the virt driver, it will be easy for us to just add any new states to be excluded, since we generally require nova is upgraded after ironic.

 > * retiring a node should probably be possible from any state

Possibly, but I'm also think it is fine to focus on cases where we know we can move with-in the workflow. outside of workflow cases... I wonder if we should let nature identify them for us.

 > * support could be combined with a feature discussed at the ptg:
 > "taking nodes out of service without deleting them"

Discussions seemed very keen on kind of having the same pattern, although I feel state and process mechanics are different. Workflows that would result are different and I think it is okay if we need to make changes to the flow/process to support each that are different, as long as they are consistently different... if that makes sense.

 > 
 > [1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/ironic/2019/ironic.2019-05-13-15.10.log.html'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-11-20 16:53:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Node retirement was discussed at the PTG in Shanghai:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/010789.html

TL;DR:
* retirement is different from out-of-service and should be handled differently;
* the logic should be similar to maintenance/maintenance reason, i.e. a flag not a state;
* the implementation should follow what is done for protected (following Dmitry's suggestion);

I'll update the spec accordingly."}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-11-22 12:33:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-11-22 12:35:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-11-22 12:59:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-11-22 13:07:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-11-22 13:45:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

nothing to add, not adding a vote as I'm mentioned as assignee, but as far as I'm concerned, it basically reflects what was discussed during the PTG
thanks!"}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-12-02 13:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-12-02 14:02:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-12-02 14:03:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-12-03 11:19:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

Looks great, just one thing: I think we should prevent an available node to become retired. Otherwise a node ends up in an awkward self-conflicting state, which will cause backward compatibility problems with older API consumers.'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-12-03 17:23:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(5 comments)

Thanks, Dmitry. 

If I understand correctly, your main suggestion would be to not allow the 'retired' flag to be set on 'available' nodes which would:

- remove the need for any nova changes
- ensure backwards compatibility with other tools (like metalsmith)
- require the admin to move a node to manageable first

Is that about right?"}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-12-03 17:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Well, you actually said this explicitly in your summary, sorry :)
Sounds good for me.'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-12-03 17:39:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-12-03 22:21:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-12-03 22:23:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-12-04 07:38:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Thanks for the review, Julia.

I think one can argue both ways for 'retired' being set when a node is in state available:

- pro: it makes things easier when retiring nodes as a whole delivery can be marked irrespective of the nodes' states

- contra: it seems somewhat conflicting to be 'available' and retired at the same time

I'm good with excluding available for now. If it turns out that this inconvenient, we can always reconsider how to handle this."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-12-04 12:40:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-12-04 12:43:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Good point Arne, it's easier to permit something later that to disallow.

My problem with permitting available+retired is that any existing tool will ignore the retired flag. If we decide to disallow deployment on such nodes, it will cause older nova to go into retries and break older metalsmith (bifrost, etc) completely. We'd also have to update allocation API to be aware of the retired flag."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-12-04 12:44:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2

I'm good with the proposal now. I'll leave it open for any late reviews, ping me for approval in 1-2 days otherwise."}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2019-12-06 15:33:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2

Thank you Arne.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-12-06 16:23:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add support for node retirement

This spec proposes to add initial support for node retirement.

Story: #2005425
Task: #30455

Change-Id: Ib97d2b31256dcc356896028ac1b57ca436976bdd

subject: Set CentOS upgrade jobs to non-voting

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-05 22:07:37.000000000', 'message': "Set CentOS upgrade jobs to non-voting

As centos upgrade jobs instantly ends up in timout error as
they take more than 3 hours pretty frequently, it's worth
setting them as non voting and dropping from gate.
But we still should look at the job status and we may
ignore only timeout failures, while failures for other reasons
should be investigated.

Change-Id: Iffac734d302ef5c083ac2e9f917fc3c7e4361232
(cherry picked from commit e4f3da81ce1f09a9600eda53473bed4b93a7f966)
"}]
commit_message:
Set CentOS upgrade jobs to non-voting

As centos upgrade jobs instantly ends up in timout error as
they take more than 3 hours pretty frequently, it's worth
setting them as non voting and dropping from gate.
But we still should look at the job status and we may
ignore only timeout failures, while failures for other reasons
should be investigated.

Change-Id: Iffac734d302ef5c083ac2e9f917fc3c7e4361232
(cherry picked from commit e4f3da81ce1f09a9600eda53473bed4b93a7f966)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-27 08:51:11.000000000', 'message': "Extend NeutronFixture to allow live migration with ports

None of our functional live migration tests uses neutron ports. Simply
adding a port to the boot request shows that the live migration step of
the tests fails because the compute manager's
_do_pre_live_migration_from_source() call wait for vif-plugged events
from Neutron but our Neutron fixture does not send it.

This does not cause problem during a simple boot because during boot the
virt driver triggers the waiting for the vif-plug event and in the
functional test we have a FakeDriver that does not do it.

This patch implements the simplest solution to make it possible to test
live migration with neutron ports. It simply turns off the waiting by
setting CONF.vif_plugging_timeout to 0

A nicer solution would be to extend either the Neutron fixture or the
fake virt driver to send vif-plug event at certain triggers. But that
would require a lot more surgery.

This patch is a prerequisite to later patches covering live migration
with qos neutron ports.

blueprint: support-move-ops-with-qos-ports-ussuri

Change-Id: I63c1109dcdb9132cdbc41010654c5fdb31a4fe31

A nicer solution would be to extend either the Neutron fixture or the

would require a lot more surgery.

This patch is a prerequisite to later patches covering live migration

blueprint: support-move-ops-with-qos-ports-ussuri

Change-Id: I63c1109dcdb9132cdbc41010654c5fdb31a4fe31

commit_message:
Extend NeutronFixture to allow live migration with ports

None of our functional live migration tests uses neutron ports. Simply
adding a port to the boot request shows that the live migration step of
the tests fails because the compute manager's
_do_pre_live_migration_from_source() call wait for vif-plugged events
from Neutron but our Neutron fixture does not send it.

This does not cause problem during a simple boot because during boot the
virt driver triggers the waiting for the vif-plug event and in the
functional test we have a FakeDriver that does not do it.

This patch implements the simplest solution to make it possible to test
live migration with neutron ports. It simply turns off the waiting by
setting CONF.vif_plugging_timeout to 0

A nicer solution would be to extend either the Neutron fixture or the
fake virt driver to send vif-plug event at certain triggers. But that
would require a lot more surgery.

This patch is a prerequisite to later patches covering live migration
with qos neutron ports.

blueprint: support-move-ops-with-qos-ports-ussuri

Change-Id: I63c1109dcdb9132cdbc41010654c5fdb31a4fe31

commit_message:
Log exact error during getting value from file

Before this patch function get_value_from_file() was only
logging something like "Unable to access {filename}" but it
would be useful sometimes to check what was exact reason of
IOError so lets log this info also.

TrivialFix

Related-bug: #1853652

Change-Id: I28b1753a8d5767babbb6f06a581ffe1fc4ad75d3

commit_message:
Install mariadb-client for mysqldump command

When using the nova to placement db migration script, debian users will have
issues using the mysqldump command as the mariadb-client-core package doesn't
include this command. The packages installed for the other distros do install
mysqldump alongside more tooling, this would bring debian to feature parity.

db migration script:
https://opendev.org/openstack/placement/raw/branch/master/placement_db_tools/mysql-migrate-db.sh

What we currently have:
https://packages.ubuntu.com/disco/amd64/mariadb-client-core-10.3/filelist
What we could have:
https://packages.ubuntu.com/disco/amd64/mariadb-client-10.3/filelist
Example of what an other distro gets:
see line 543, # mariadb-client.files
https://build.opensuse.org/package/view_file/server:database/mariadb/mariadb.spec

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/696865
Change-Id: I50b1cde1a82a855d54c54b43f8d141df9583205c
(cherry picked from commit b89d5a94fe8f5b7002415438863efff705b31aa8)

I guess we can abandon this for now?'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-12-06 10:01:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

yeah, we can apply this fix sometime in the future while we add volume-type support for non-admin users.'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-12-06 10:04:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > It was noted by our support while debugging a different problem.

As non-admin users can also see the volume-types as per cinder-policy[1].
[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/policies/volume_type.py#L52-L71'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-12-06 11:16:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree to abandon this.

I don't think regular users manage volume types even when we migrate to the policy based approach because it requires knowledge on the infrastructure.

Regular users can see volume types, but it is already covered in the project volume panel including volume creation.

Thus, I don't think we need to change this at the moment."}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2019-12-06 14:04:22.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Don't require admin rights to display volume types

Check for user permissions before getting volume type information, so
that users who don't have the access to qos_specs still can see the
types.

commit_message:
block diag quota scenarios

This document is an exploration space for the various kinds of
Quota models that might exist in a world that has hierarchical
project relationships.

Co-Authored-By: John Garbutt<john@johngarbutt.com>

Change-Id: Iff569ded5b06cd8c48877a12d1aee5d239d02013

commit_message:
Move the legacy telemetry environment template to correct location

The deployment directory is not the right place for environment
templates. Hences the relative paths end up as file not found.

Change-Id: Ia2961f22d5bf1afbe6f5c1dd7bf7eb762d4c6e53

commit_message:
Update local.conf.sample to match stable/train

This patch is adjusting the local.conf.sample file to match the
stable/train release. Without these changes, using the local.conf.sample
file to deploy devstack will fail.

Change-Id: Ibf8282585c6a4931d5662ad3e2f8a65bfd375624
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Set Ansible SIG URL to wiki

The wiki tracks history and retains content better
than the etherpad. Until there's a formal document
repo for the SIG, let's use it instead.

Change-Id: I073df654cc9eaa477c22a78c45e20bc2580b87c1

Good question... It seems like the tempest test should hit some of that integration, but I defer to people more aware of the test coverage of the various nova jobs.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-05 19:19:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The libvirt driver uses os-brick for anything related to volumes and we have a lot of compute/volume related tests in our existing jobs we run against this, so I'd think we're covered. I don't really know what else we'd do to tweak something to try and expose a failure. Thinks *just working* and jobs passing is likely good enough indication that what was removed was in fact no longer needed since os-brick is privsep-native (and has been for a long time)."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-05 19:25:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

run-Quobyte CI'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-12-05 19:27:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thanks to mikal, nova was fully transitioned to using privsep over
the past cycles. However the old rootwrap filter definitions have been
left behind, which basically means that there is limited security
benefit right now (code gone rogue could still call rootwrap to execute
some code as root).

As far as I can tell, those can be removed now. os-brick calls in
compute.filters should be covered by the os_brick.privileged.default
context. Filters in api-metadata.filters and network.filters are not
used anymore.

Rootwrap is now only used to launch the two privileged privsep contexts.
Since those are one-shot at the start of the service, there is little
point in using rootwrap-daemon on nova nodes.

Old config files, now empty, are kept around to avoid breaking any
deployment tool that relies on their presence on upgrade.

Change-Id: Ie5e5ab17dabad713d4ad1261ab8b5d62b017f31e

Rootwrap is now only used to launch the two privileged privsep contexts.

Change-Id: Ie5e5ab17dabad713d4ad1261ab8b5d62b017f31e
'}]
commit_message:
Remove unused rootwrap filters

Thanks to mikal, nova was fully transitioned to using privsep over
the past cycles. However the old rootwrap filter definitions have been
left behind, which basically means that there is limited security
benefit right now (code gone rogue could still call rootwrap to execute
some code as root).

As far as I can tell, those can be removed now. os-brick calls in
compute.filters should be covered by the os_brick.privileged.default
context.

Rootwrap is now only used to launch the two privileged privsep contexts.
Since those are one-shot at the start of the service, there is little
point in using rootwrap-daemon on nova nodes.

network.filters and api-metadata.filters are being removed in
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/696518 as part of the nova-net cleanup.

Change-Id: Ie5e5ab17dabad713d4ad1261ab8b5d62b017f31e

commit_message:
iptables save fix for centos 7

Centos 7 use systemd, we cannot use service save iptables anymore.
iptables can be stopped and disabled so we just save rules in
/etc/sysconfig/iptables with iptables-save

Change-Id: I55342afadea29a1a07fe50f30e0371b3367c3d7a
Closes-Bug: 1831175
(cherry picked from commit 7b421516799722490ddffed9ce7e9179dd5fe2cc)

commit_message:
Add nginx_ingress_controller_chart_tag

Additioanlly, bumping up the Chart version to 1.24.7 without which the
ingress controller fails to deploy on 1.16.x.

Additionally, bump up nginx_ingress_controller_tag version to 0.26.1.
This is to ensure that we are running an up to date nginx ingress
controller with fixes for known CVEs.

Story: 2006853
Task: 37444

Change-Id: Ibf045a06d19b02095e19d9a21d14a91a39a3751c

[{'created': '2019-11-26 22:59:05.000000000', 'message': '[k8s] Fix rolling upgrade with podman

There are some small regression issues introduced by the podman
support patch. And another issue is since k8s v1.16, the daemonsets
has been moved app/v1 from extensions[1], so we need to update the
system:node-drainer ClusterRole so that kubectl can be called on
worker node to trigger the drain process. Both issues are fixed
in this patch.

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/release/notes/#deprecations-and-removals

commit_message:
[k8s] Fix rolling upgrade with podman

There are some small regression issues introduced by the podman
support patch. And another issue is since k8s v1.16, the daemonsets
has been moved app/v1 from extensions[1], so we need to update the
system:node-drainer ClusterRole so that kubectl can be called on
worker node to trigger the drain process. Both issues are fixed
in this patch.

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/release/notes/#deprecations-and-removals

Task: 37642
Story: 2005201

Change-Id: I87ed49fd1e9cd513ae54f6758717379adafae3a4

[{'created': '2019-11-20 16:35:33.000000000', 'message': 'bug: Only query Cinder API if volume size > 0

Only query Cinder API for volume type if volume size is greater than 0.
This is to make sure that Magnum does not have a hard dependency on
Cinder and works without the Cinder API enlisted as an endpoint.

This regression was introduced in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/621734/
where boot from volume support was introduced. See
https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2005386#comment-147555 for
more details of the error.

commit_message:
bug: Only query Cinder API if volume size > 0

Only query Cinder API for volume type if volume size is greater than 0.
This is to make sure that Magnum does not have a hard dependency on
Cinder and works without the Cinder API enlisted as an endpoint.

This regression was introduced in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/621734/
where boot from volume support was introduced. See
https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2005386#comment-147555 for
more details of the error.

Story: 2005386
Task: 37565

Change-Id: I1bdec0c11a18bea9143fb4792a0a2e4ba5dc1fcf

commit_message:
Change k8s-keystone-auth docker repo

Reverts the change in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/643225/22 (line 9).
This allows users to deploy clusters with all released versions of
cloud-provider-openstack. The openstackmagnum repo only has v1.14.0

Also updates the docs with the default value for the Train release.

Story: 2006967
Task: 37693
Change-Id: Icf6f9f3c02d6b211c4dc3c1d654c8d8573443e0f
(cherry picked from commit 9910925da98f251dc9417dea8342cb0af54595d4)

[{'created': '2019-11-21 20:34:19.000000000', 'message': 'Add "prev" link to instance page list pagination

Currently there is no link to previous page at paginated instances
table. This patch resolves that issue by re-using the pagination
code for flavors.

It also supports Ying Zuo's scenario:
After I set only 1 item per page and deleted the instance on the first page,
the expected behavior is showing the next instance in the table after one is
deleted.

xxxIndexView uses PagedTableMixin's _get_marker() from now instead of GET()-
ing the markers

commit_message:
Add "prev" link to instance page list pagination

Currently there is no link to previous page at paginated instances
table. This patch resolves that issue by re-using the pagination
code for flavors.

It also supports Ying Zuo's scenario:
After I set only 1 item per page and deleted the instance on the first page,
the expected behavior is showing the next instance in the table after one is
deleted.

xxxIndexView uses PagedTableMixin's _get_marker() from now instead of GET()-
ing the markers

Closes-Bug: #1274427
Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Ratushnyy <dratushn@cisco.com>
Co-Authored-By: Akihiro Motoki <amotoki@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Id8eaae6bf1b5d6f42291291655e14b8715c08bc8
Signed-off-by: Ferenc Cserepkei <ferenc.cserepkei@ericsson.com>
(cherry picked from commit 467669417979ec7443d5195d4b4635d5596cdc08)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-03 13:49:33.000000000', 'message': "[OVN] Don't register OVN models yet

networking-ovn merge is still not completed yet. Until the point where
Neutron networking-ovn driver starts using DB models from Neutron tree,
the DB models won't be registered to the global metadata, otherwise when
using networking-ovn, OVN models are registered twice - once from
Neutron, once from networking-ovn.

Change-Id: If9bad32febd4874952ffbad19197965df43f2178
"}]
commit_message:
[OVN] Don't register OVN models yet

networking-ovn merge is still not completed yet. Until the point where
Neutron networking-ovn driver starts using DB models from Neutron tree,
the DB models won't be registered to the global metadata, otherwise when
using networking-ovn, OVN models are registered twice - once from
Neutron, once from networking-ovn.

Change-Id: If9bad32febd4874952ffbad19197965df43f2178

commit_message:
NetcatTester.stop_processes skip "No such process" exception

If any of the processes, client or server, spawned by NetcatTester is
not present during the stop command (kill signal sent), by default the
method will not raise an exception.

Change-Id: If8cf47a01dc353734ad07ca6cd4db7bec6c90fb6
Closes-Bug: #1852869
(cherry picked from commit 728d8ee4b1b9fd6a99ebbd66a0e30e81a078a5b5)

commit_message:
bug: Use configured heat-container-agent tag

Remove hard coded reference to train-dev which ends up pulling multiple
images down and use HEAT_CONTAINER_AGENT_TAG instead.

Also add missing CONTAINER_INFRA_PREFIX.

Story: 2006459
Task: 37566

Change-Id: Ic8d0e3ba125ef6ce7fde68c086ccbdb4730ac4a6
(cherry picked from commit b2cc1c237c0aa221d87bc72fcb500e3d16d17128)

commit_message:
Replace git.openstack.org with opendev.org

This patch replaces git.openstack.org with opendev.org as redirection
from old path was enabled.
Also we change upper constraints url due to [1]

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/006478.html

Change-Id: I987630d0af1354b5c74c00c1ba0f76e2c80bed7e
